title: 107_s3105
content: The Act may be cited as the "West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act" and includes a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases. Section 319 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases. The Secretary may make grants to States for prevention and control, with preference given to states with a substantial incidence or prevalence of the diseases. The temporary program under Section 319 of the Public Health Service Act provides grants to States for prevention and control of West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases. Funds are to be used for developing mosquito control plans and programs on vector-borne diseases to support prevention efforts and training for a competent workforce. Matching funds and limitations on supplanting are also outlined. The State must provide assurances to the Secretary for a grant under Section 319 of the Public Health Service Act, ensuring non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of program costs. Contributions can be in cash or in kind, including equipment or services. Federal contributions required under subparagraph (A) can be in cash or in kind, including plant, equipment, or services. Amounts provided by the Federal Government or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be counted as non-Federal contributions. Grants under this subsection should supplement, not replace, State and local funds for similar activities. The Secretary may waive contribution requirements for a State due to extraordinary economic conditions. States receiving funds must involve local participation to the extent possible. The State may receive a waiver for contribution requirements due to economic conditions. Local involvement is required in planning and implementing mosquito control plans. A significant portion of the grant must be spent at the local level. Technical assistance can be provided by the CDC to support state and local health departments. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention can provide technical support to State and local health departments for mosquito control programs and arboviral diseases. A limitation of 20 percent of the funds can be used for this purpose. Guidelines for mosquito abatement will be developed in consultation with health and mosquito control organizations. The plan will provide guidelines for sustainable, locally managed mosquito control programs, including identifying new cases, tracking disease spread, laboratory support, increasing surveillance, and conducting educational outreach campaigns. The West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act aims to increase participation in surveillance systems for arboviruses, conduct educational outreach campaigns, and outline procedures for mosquito control. The Secretary will evaluate the program and submit a report to Congress within 18 months of enactment. The subsection includes evaluation results, sustainable mosquito abatement program development, progress on guidelines implementation, and overall program costs and benefits. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 and 2004, with additional funding for emergency control programs related to the West Nile Virus. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 and 2004, with additional funding for emergency control programs related to the West Nile Virus. The program established under this subsection shall terminate on September 30, 2004, with a possible extension for an additional fiscal year based on evaluation results. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section for an Arbovirus Research Program. The President is mandated to enhance research on controlling insect populations that transmit diseases like West Nile Virus, develop screening tools, pathogen inactivation technologies, and containment methodologies. Activities may involve examining existing and new control methods and can be carried out by various entities including the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences. Coordination between relevant Federal agencies, the private sector, and individuals with expertise in public health, entomology, arbovirology, and veterinary health is promoted. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 through 2007.
